Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 54391-001 
Transaction Technical Assistance Cluster (C-TRTA) 
November 2020 
 
 
Technical Assistance for Gender Mainstreaming and 
Gender Initiatives in Nonsovereign Operations 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Access to Information 
Policy.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
ACFP    Australian Climate Finance Partnership 
OP2  –  ADB’s Operational Plan for Priority 2 (OP2): Accelerating Progress 
in Gender Equality, 2019–2024 
PSOD  –  Private Sector Operations Department 
TA  –  Technical Assistance 
TASF  –  ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund 
WAVES  –  We-Fi-funded Women Accelerating Vibrant Enterprises In Southeast 
Asia and the Pacific Program 
We-Fi  –  Women Entrepreneurs Finance Initiative 
 
 
NOTE 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars 
 
Vice-President  Ashok  Lavasa,  Private  Sector  Operations  and  Public-Private 
Partnerships 
Director General  Michael Barrow, Private Sector Operations Department (PSOD) 
Director  Mark Kunzer, Private Sector Transaction Support Division (PSTS), 
PSOD 
   
Team leader  Amanda  Satterly,  Senior  Social  Development  (Gender  and 
Development) Specialist, PSTS, PSOD 
Team members  Genevieve Abel, Principal Transaction Support Specialist (Integrity), 
PSOD 
David Barton, Senior Investment Specialist, PSOD 
Dominic Patrick Mellor, Principal Investment Specialist, PSOD 
Naja Pareja Penas, Associate Transaction Support Officer, PSOD 
Gema Perez Lopez, Investment Specialist, PSOD 
Sherwin Pu, Principal Investment Specialist, PSOD 
Sabine Spohn, Senior Investment Specialist, PSOD  
Anne  Valko  Celestino,  Social  Development  (Gender  and 
Development) Specialist, PSTS, PSOD 
 
 
In preparing any country program or strategy, financing any project, or by making any designation 
of  or  reference  to  a  particular  territory  or  geographic  area  in  this  document,  the  Asian 
Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any 
territory or area.

CONTENTS 
Page 
 
TRANSACTION TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AT A GLANCE 
I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLUSTER  2 
A.  Analysis of Key Issues  2 
B.  Justification for Cluster Modality  3 
C.  Outcome and Outputs  3 
D.  Cost and Indicative Financing  4 
E.  Implementation Arrangements  4 
II.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  6 
 
APPENDIXES 
1.  Summary of Subprojects  7 
2.  Subproject Descriptions  8

2 
 
I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLUSTER 
 
A.  Analysis of Key Issues 
 
1.  Asia and the Pacific has made progress in some areas of gender equality, yet important 
gaps remain in education completion, health outcomes, employment, and participation and 
leadership in decision-making. As a key driver of growth and an engine for 90% of jobs in 
developing countries, the private sector represents a source of opportunities to drive greater 
gender equality.1  Seeking to increase gender equality through business is not only the right thing 
to do, it is the smart thing to do. Gender equality is critical to business performance and 
sustainable economic growth. Diversity in businesses has been estimated to result in about 21% 
higher profitability than companies with low gender diversity on their executive teams.2 Internships, 
mentoring programs and networking platforms are shown to drive productivity in a range of areas 
including  increased  female  entrepreneurship,  women’s  greater  participation  in  science, 
technology, engineering and mathematics, and increased access to leadership opportunities. 
Human resources policies on diversity and work flexibility provide opportunities to transform 
gender norms for mothers and fathers while contributing to greater income security, career 
development and job opportunities. Corporate practices on zero tolerance for gender-based 
violence  and  harassment  increase  profitability  by  reducing  turnover,  increasing  worker 
productivity and increasing company access to the entire talent pool, while also reducing barriers 
for women in the workplace.3  
 
2.  The Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) Private Sector Operations Department (PSOD) 
aims to achieve effective gender mainstreaming in alignment with ADB Strategy 20304 and ADB 
Operational Plan for Priority 2 (OP2) Accelerating Progress in Gender Equality, 2019–20245 
which sets ambitious at-entry targets according to its gender categorization system.6  
 
3.  Historically in PSOD, the financial and agribusiness sectors - followed by the education 
sector - account for the majority of transactions with the greatest number of development 
indicators aimed at reducing inequalities or accelerating progress in gender equality. However, 
non-traditional sectors such as information, communication and technology, and energy are 
becoming increasingly more gender-sensitive. Likewise, more efforts are being made to further 
improve gender mainstreaming across all sectors of PSOD operations, including transport, private 
equity financing and manufacturing. Furthermore, enhancing gender outcomes is being taken into 
 
1 UN Global Compact Women’s Empowerment Principles. COVID-19 and Gender Equality: a Call to Action for the 
Private Sector. April 2020. 
2 McKinsey Global Institute. The Power of Parity: Advancing Women’s Equality In Asia Pacific. McKinsey & Company. 
April 2018. 
3 McKinsey Global Institute reports the examples of a global mining company that found its ten most gender-diverse 
sites performing 15% better than other sites because of superior safety and productivity records or of an international 
hospitality and services company that found that teams made up of 40 to 60% women boost brand image by 5% and 
increase customer retention by 12%. In McKinsey Global Institute. The Power of Parity: Advancing Women’s Equality 
In Asia Pacific. McKinsey & Company. April 2018. 
4 Asian Development Bank Strategy 2030 Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the 
Pacific. July 2018. 
5 Asian Development Bank. September 2019. Strategy 2030 Operational Plan for Priority 2: Accelerating Progress in 
Gender Equality, 2019-2024. Manila.  
6 All ADB operations are classified into one of the four gender categories: gender equity theme, effective gender 
mainstreaming, some gender elements, and no gender elements. The gender categories are defined in ADB’s 
Guidelines for Gender Mainstreaming Categories of ADB Projects (2012) and the gender targets are further 
described in ADB Strategy 2030 Operational Plan For Priority 2 Accelerating Progress In Gender Equality, 2019–
2024 (2019).

3 
account both in new business developments and investment programs, for example under climate 
finance, venture financing, and digital finance.  
 
4.  It is anticipated that greater consideration to include gender measures in PSOD’s 2020 
pipeline7 and beyond will continue, notably with enhanced ADB resources through the recently 
created PSOD Gender Team.8 
 
B.  Justification for Cluster Modality 
 
5.  PSOD has access to a number of financial  sources which seek to support gender 
initiatives. These financial sources have been secured through a range of financing vehicles which 
need to be programmed in order to be utilized. PSOD’s Gender Team seeks to pool these funds 
under the umbrella of a transactional technical assistance project (TA) to ensure coordination and 
management  of  these  funds.  Secured  sources  of  funding  initially  include  the  Women 
Entrepreneurs Finance Initiative (We-Fi), the Australian Climate Finance Partnership (ACFP) and 
the ADB Ventures Financing Partnership Facility9 (see Appendix 1 on funding sources by TA 
subproject). The objectives of each financing source will be presented in the respective sub-
projects, which will be processed in accordance with the interests and agreements of the funding 
source. 
 
6.  The transaction TA cluster will provide capacity building support to PSOD programs and 
projects with adequate resources to develop capacities and  knowledge in response to the greater 
attention given by international development partners and finance institutions, including ADB, to 
a more systematic inclusion of measures supporting gender equality and women’s empowerment 
as part of private sector development projects. As such, the TA cluster proposes to (i) support 
private sector projects categorized as Effective Gender Mainstreaming or Gender Equity Theme 
under ADB categorization system to implement their gender action plans; (ii) increase women’s 
access to finance in the Pacific for women’s businesses through the WAVES Program; (iii) 
enhance  gender  mainstreaming  in  climate  finance  projects  under  the  ACFP;  (iv)  develop 
knowledge and tools to promote gender-lens financing by financial institutions; and (v) enhance 
gender  mainstreaming  in  venture  capital  financing  operations.  Further  details  on  these 
subprojects are provided in Appendix 2.  
 
C.  Outcome and Outputs 
 
7.  Overall outcome. The TA cluster will have the following overall outcome: improved quality 
of gender responsiveness in private sector investments. 
 
8.  Each TA subproject will generally deliver all or some of the following outputs, as to be 
specified by each transaction TA subproject proposal. 
 
9.  Output  1:  Improved  capacities  of  ADB  private  sector  clients  to  develop  and 
implement gender mainstreaming initiatives and gender action plans (delivered under 
subprojects 1, 2, 3 and 4). The TA will increase PSOD’s clients’ understanding of how gender 
mainstreaming applies to their business and will enhance their ability to develop more gender 
equitable business offerings, more conducive work environment for gender equality and women’s 
 
7 ADB. July 2020. Private Sector Operations in 2019 Report on Development Effectiveness. Manila 
8 PSOD recruited its first Gender Advisor in August 2019.  As of July 2020, PSOD’s Gender Team is composed of two 
International Gender Specialist staff and three gender consultants, with the support of Gender Champions from 
PSOD staff). 
9 ADB Ventures Financing Partnership Facility

4 
 
empowerment.  Capacity  building  will  also  be  provided  to  improve  on their monitoring  and 
reporting of gender action plans.  
 
10.  Output 2: Increased capacity of ADB Private Sector Investment Programs to deliver 
transformational, industry-specific gender measures (delivered under subprojects 3, 4 and 
5). Targeted programs here include sector-specific financing programs established under PSOD, 
in particular but not limited to the microfinance, climate finance and venture finance facilities. The 
TA will serve to support these programs to better integrate gender elements into their project 
identification and project designs. Capacity building activities under this output may consist of (i) 
support to PSOD investment teams during project preparation and due diligence to strengthen 
the gender value proposition and (ii) guidelines development on gender mainstreaming in targeted 
industries to better inform the gender design.  
 
11.  Output 3: Enhanced business and other skills of women-owned small and medium-
sized enterprises (delivered under subprojects 2, 3 and 4). Tailored training, business mentoring 
or other support will be applied to assist women to grow more profitable businesses. The TA will 
look at introducing innovative business practices such as the use of digital tools and solutions to 
bring  value  to  the  enterprise,  drive  operational  efficiency,  and  open  new  opportunities  for 
expansion and scale. The TA will provide targeted networking and mentoring opportunities, 
information and awareness-raising workshops, or other forms of capacity building in areas 
relevant to women to increase their business resilience, work-family balance and reinforce the 
cross-functional capacities for their economic empowerment.  
 
12.  Output 4: Generation of knowledge (delivered under subprojects 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5). The 
TA will support the development of knowledge products which may include case studies, tip 
sheets, guidance notes, research papers, blog posts, market analysis or electronic materials 
(including videos) on relevant topics, sectors or countries. The knowledge products may also 
include training, communication and marketing materials for use in implementing gender action 
plans. Under this output, support to ADB private sector stakeholders will be considered as 
resource persons in peer-learning summits and external forums to strengthen their gender 
awareness and promote skills-transfer knowledge.  
 
D.  Cost and Indicative Financing 
 
13.  The TA cluster is expected not to exceed $5,000,000. It will be financed on a grant-basis 
by multiple donors, including but not limited to ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF), 
We-Fi and ACFP. Detailed cost estimates and financing arrangements will be presented in each 
TA subproject proposal submitted for approval. ADB will seek cost-matching from its clients, 
where possible. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  The TA cluster will run for an initial period of five years from January 2021 to December 
2025. The gender team in ADB’s Private Sector Technical Support division will administer the TA 
cluster. The TA will be applied to activities across all PSOD divisions. Some subprojects may be 
implemented by another PSOD division. A OneADB approach will be sought when applicable, 
notably in the implementation of the TA subproject 1 to encourage exchanges across fields of 
expertise to capitalize on ADB knowledge of effective gender mainstreaming across countries 
and sectors. Implementation details will be presented in each subproject as they are prepared. 
Each TA subproject proposal will be submitted for approval to Director General, PSOD, in 
accordance with the business process for transaction TA cluster processing.

5 
 
Table 1: Implementation Arrangements for the Technical Assistance Cluster 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative implementation  January 2021 – December 2025  
period for the TA cluster

method

WSME and Financial  Subproject 2 
Sector Development 
Gender and Climate  Individual selection  Asian Development Bank, 
Change Financing  Subproject 3 
Specialist

Alternative Financial 
Markets 
Advance contracting and  Use of advance contracting or retroactive financing will be specified in each subproject 
retroactive financing  proposal, if necessary. Advanced contracting will only be used for early recruitment 
purposes. No contracts will be signed with consultants until subprojects have been 
approved. 
Disbursement  The TA resources will be disbursed following ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
Use of advance payment facility or reimbursement will be assessed and specified in each 
subproject proposal.} 
 
15.  Subprojects. The TA cluster is expected to have five subprojects which are described in 
Appendix 2. Each subproject will be designed in accordance with the general output descriptions 
(paras. 8–11) as and when needed during the implementation period. The subprojects are not 
mutually dependent and may be presented and approved in any order. Additional subprojects 
may be developed, and additional sources of financing may be identified. Not all subprojects may 
materialize. The purpose of this TA cluster is to ensure flexibility in accessing resources for gender 
programming.

6 
 
Table 2: Indicative Implementation Period and Budget Allocation for Subprojects 
Item  Subproject Title  Implementation Period  Budget 
Subproject 1  TA to Strengthen Implementation of  Jan 2021 – December 2023  $ 1,500,000 
Gender Mainstreaming in 
Nonsovereign Investments 
Subproject 2  WAVES Program’s Private Sector  Jan 2021 – December 2024  $ 1,250,000 
Development in Pacific Countries TA

TA 
Subproject 5  ADB Ventures Gender Mainstreaming  Jan 2021 – December 2023  $ 75,000* 
TA = Technical Assistance, ADB = Asian Development Bank, ACFP = Australian Climate Finance Partnership 
* Indicative amount  
Source: Asian Development Bank.  
 
16.  Consulting services. ADB’s Private Sector Transaction Support gender team will recruit 
an individual international consultant under the first subproject processed to act as a TA cluster 
Program Coordinator for the duration of the TA. This consultant will oversee the tasks and 
deliverables for each subproject and will report on fund use and performance. ADB will engage 
this Program Coordinator, and all other consultants engaged under subprojects, in accordance 
with the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project 
administration instructions and/or staff instructions. Where procurement of goods or works is 
anticipated, it will be presented under each subproject. 
 
17.  Cofinancier requirements. The TA cluster will consist of subprojects financed by either 
ADB and/or donor funding. Each TA subproject financed by donor funding will be designed in 
accordance  with  the  trust  fund’s  requirements.  Eligibility,  implementation,  monitoring  and 
reporting provisions will be specified in the TA subproject proposals. 
 
 
II.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $5,000,000 on a grant basis for 
the Technical Assistance for Gender Mainstreaming and Gender Initiatives in Nonsovereign 
Operations, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 1  7 
SUMMARY OF SUBPROJECTS

Appendix 2  8 
 
SUBPROJECT DESCRIPTIONS 
 
Subproject 1  Technical Assistance to Strengthen Implementation of Gender 
Mainstreaming in Nonsovereign Investments 
Indicative outputs and activities  Indicative outputs: more gender equal business offerings by PSOD 
clients, more conducive PSOD clients’ work environment for gender 
equality and women’s empowerment, enhanced capacity of PSOD 
clients to implement and report on gender equality initiatives and GAPs. 
Indicative  activities: capacity building  of  PSOD clients on  gender-
responsive product structuring, production of case studies, capacity 
advisory services on gender-inclusive policies and training modules, 
capacity building on sex-disaggregated data reporting. 
Indicative implementation  PSOD Gender Team as the Technical Assistance Supervising Unit.. 
arrangements 
Implementation schedule  2021-2023 
Subproject 2  WAVES  Program’s  Private  Sector  Development  in  Pacific 
Countries Technical Assistance 
Indicative outputs and activities  Indicative outputs: increased women’s access to finance in the Pacific, 
strengthened  capacities  of  partner  financial  institutions,  capacity 
development of WSMEs. 
Indicative  activities  as  defined  in  the  WeFi  WAVES  Program’s 
components for its activities and targets in the Pacific: capacity building 
to enhance partner financial institution’s capacity to provide innovative 
gender-inclusive services and products to WSMEs, market scoping for 
innovative financial technologies catered to WSME, capacity building to 
develop gender-responsive digital finance solutions, training activities 
to WSME clients in the Pacific.  
Indicative implementation  Implementation of the TA activities will be conducted by PSFI, in 
arrangements  coordination with PSOD Gender Team and SDCC to recruit specific 
consultant services for each output activity and reporting to We-Fi.  
Implementation schedule  2021-2024 
Subproject 3  Australian  Climate  Finance  Partnership  Gender  Initiatives 
Technical Assistance 
Indicative outputs and activities  Indicative  outputs:  Women  and  girls  empowered  through  gender 
initiatives in at least 60% of the projects financed by ACFP, guidelines 
and  knowledge  products  on  gender  and  climate  finance  in 
nonsovereign operations. 
Indicative activities:  
(a) Capacity building to better integrate gender elements into non-
sovereign projects in the Fund’s target countries  
(b) Gender-focused initiatives in core project activities, which aim to 
address a gender gap or inequality. The activities can include instituting 
sex-disaggregated job reporting in investee companies, supporting 
skills development and/or leadership programs for women employees 
within investee companies, setting appropriate job targets to increase 
share of skilled jobs for women, establishing or improving human 
resource policies/practices to improve institutional gender equality, 
establishing extended consultation processes for projects with women's 
groups in communities affected by a project, encouraging contractors

Appendix 2  9 
to increase participation of women in providing services to projects , 
strengthening systems for prevention of sexual abuse, exploitation and 
harassment 
(c) Gender based initiatives in non-core project activities such as 
providing capacity and awareness-raising programs for women on 
energy/water  consumption,  or  health-related  programs,  supporting 
programs to improve the livelihoods of women and girls in communities 
affected by a project, supporting increased access to finance for women 
entrepreneurs 
(d) Knowledge sharing over time such that lessons learned from the 
Fund’s  integration  of  gender  initiatives  into  non-sovereign  climate 
finance operations are disseminated to wider audiences to promote 
replication and scale up.  
Indicative implementation  PSOD Gender Team as the Technical Assistance Supervising Unit, to 
arrangements  recruit  international  and  national  consultants  to  provide  gender 
expertise to ACFP.  
Implementation schedule  2021-2025 
Subproject 4  Gender-lens Financing Development Technical Assistance 
Indicative outputs and activities  Indicative outputs: greater access to finance for women and women-
led/women-owned businesses, knowledge sharing on financial and 
non-financial services.  
Indicative activities: generation of knowledge products, support to PSFI 
to improve gender-lens financing transactions, to financial institutions 
and to women in business via sponsorships to enhance peer learning 
development and knowledge transfer. 
Indicative implementation  PSOD Gender Team as the Technical Assistance Supervising Unit, to 
arrangements  recruit consultant services on gender financing. Implementation of the 
TA activities will be conducted in consultation with PSFI. 
Implementation schedule  2021-2025 
Subproject 5  ADB Ventures Gender Mainstreaming Technical Assistance 
Indicative outputs and activities  Indicative outputs: quality capacity to design and implement gender 
measures across ADB Ventures operations. 
Indicative activities: support to ADB Venture investment team in the 
project reviews, processing and administration of gender measures, 
design of guidelines for gender mainstreaming in ADB Venture projects. 
Indicative implementation  PSOD Gender Team as the Technical Assistance Supervising Unit, to 
arrangements  recruit one consultant to provide gender expertise in ADB Ventures 
Fund’s investment activities. Implementation of the TA activities will be 
conducted in consultation with ADB Ventures Team. 
Implementation schedule  2021-2023 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, ACFP = Australian Climate Finance Partnership, We-Fi = Women Entrepreneurs 
Finance Initiative, WAVES = Women Accelerating Vibrant Enterprises In Southeast Asia And The Pacific Program, 
PSFI = Private Sector Financial Institutions Division, GAP = Gender Action Plan, WSMEs = women-owned small and 
medium-sized enterprises 
Source: Asian Development Bank.

This document dated November 2020 is provided for the ADB regional project 54391-001.
